title: What is the difference between I AM and NOT-I-IT and how to reach the NOT-I-I state?
first_phrase: This text delves into the concepts of I AM and NOT-I-I, which are states of awareness where there are no thoughts, memories, emotions, associations or perceptions. The importance of meditating on oneself before any thoughts about God is also highlighted. The last 200 tokens are part of an exercise that aims to guide individuals towards the realization of the I AM state. The exercise involves asking questions without relying on thoughts, memory, emotions, associations or perceptions. It helps to go beyond the observer-observed dyad and into the I AM state.
content: Without using your thoughts, memory, emotions, associations or perceptions, What is it that has a thousand eyes but cannot see? 7. Without using your thoughts, memory, emotions, associations or perceptions, What is it that has a thousands ears but cannot hear? Notice an experience. Observe the experience. Notice what occurs when the question is asked, "What observer is observing that"? Notice you go blank because in that "moment" you go beyond the observERobserved dyad knowER-known or experiencER-experience dyad, and into the I AM. This eventually might lead to the NOT-I-I. THE "I AM" EXERCISE #5 Guided Exercise. Eyes closed. Without using your thoughts, memory, emotions, associations or perceptions, ask yourself these questions: ( I) Without using your thoughts, memory, emotions, associations or perceptions, Are you a personality or does the personality appear within you or neither? 2. Without using your thoughts, memory, emotions, associations or perceptions, Does this personality that appears within you have form or is it formless or neither? 3.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the "I AM" exercises can help you go beyond your thoughts, memories, emotions, associations or perceptions, and tap into a deeper level of self-awareness. By exploring the observer-observed dynamic, you can reach a state of pure consciousness that can lead to a greater understanding of yourself and the world around you. Whether done individually or in a group, these exercises can be a valuable tool for personal growth and self-discovery.
